title: Action Learning Simulation Course for Leadership Development and Organizational Learning Capability Enhancement Applying Scientific Inquiry Methods

context.prior_knowledge: Basic understanding and practical experience with organizational behavior theory and leadership principles, as well as foundational knowledge of scientific inquiry methods (hypothesis formulation, observation, experimental design, data analysis).
context.additional_context: Customized training for mid-level managers in science-related public institutions requiring leadership competencies, combining scientific methodologies (inquiry, measurement, analysis) with organizational learning theory. Learners train to apply evidence-based approaches from actual scientific research processes to organizational problem-solving.

learning_goals: Cultivate ethical decision-making and leadership strategy development by applying scientific observation, variable control, and hypothesis verification processes in politically complex organizational environments.

In 4-member action learning teams, learners derive two real-world change tasks for science-related public organizations using scientific inquiry methods (brainstorming, SWOT analysis, experimental design), and submit an evidence-based report meeting institutional criteria (80% task clarity, 75% feasibility, 85% budget appropriateness) with a 12-week action plan (goals, timeline, budget, roles).

Within a six-month course, learners complete ≥3 team collaboration scenarios using simulation tools (Miro, MURAL), achieve ≥80% on the Psychological Safety Index (PSI) survey, and submit an analysis report meeting ≥4 out of 5 conflict management checklist criteria.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
